title: Monday, 27th November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:05am

Yeah, yeah, I know, we're late to start. Sorry. Hello.

BE11:05am

Where to begin, then?

BE11:06am

What about with Sir Mick.

11:05 am
BE11:06am

BE11:06am

(Davis, not Jagger.)

BE11:06am

You remember Sir Mick, right? You might remember that time he and 71 of his colleagues were wanting £140m to hang around post merging with Glencore.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

You might also remember his launch of X2, which involved setting up in some nice offices in St James's and getting $5.6bn committed from various big investors, then failing to do anything for three years.

BE11:08am

X2 turned out to be one of Noble's better investments, ironically enough .....

BE11:08am

Anyway, seems we won't have the fun of seeing him at Rio.

11:08 am
BE11:09am

https://www.ft.com...-b781-794ce08b24dc

Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 3,676, up 20.5 (+0.56%), High: 3,679, Low: 3,600, Volume: 793.01k
BE11:10am

Shareholders prefer cash in their bank accounts to being p___d up the wall on M&A. Big news.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

But we'll come back to miners later, when we run out of other stuff.

undefined
BE11:10am

So, Ocado then.

11:10 am
Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 257.10, up 18.4 (+7.71%), High: 262.50, Low: 235.80, Volume: 2.09m
BE11:10am

Slightly lower live. Up 6%.

BE11:10am

What triggered the short squeeze was this.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Uppgifter: Ocado ska lyfta Ica på nätet – affären presenteras nästa år

BE11:11am

http://www.market....esenteras-nasta-ar

BE11:11am

Beautiful language, isn't it?

11:11 am
BE11:11am

När Ica Gruppen nyligen släppte sin rapport för det tredje kvartalet var vd Per Strömberg tydlig om kedjans digitala framtid: Tidpunkten för ett centralt plocklager är snart här.
Enligt uppgifter till Icanyheter togs ett konkret beslut i början september, där representanter för samtliga profiler stod bakom en darkstore, och efter det har kedjan sökt efter chaufförer i Stockholm som ska stärka hemleveranserbjudandet i storstadsområdena, samt logistikutvecklare inom e-handeln.

BE11:11am

So the gist here is Ocado might have another international customer.

BE11:11am

Perhaps one it can name this time.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

The report above says that Icanyheter has a deal with Ocado, to be presented "at the beginning of next year".

BE11:12am

Also, Icanyheter (as in ICA, as in what used to be ICA Ahold) has been running a delivery darkstore since September, and has been hiring delivery drivers.

BE11:12am

"It's no secret that we look [towards Scandinavia], but more than I cannot say," Sverker Lindbo, Business Development Manager at Ocado, is quoted as saying.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Now, I'm a wee bit unclear whether this is a new deal or the deal that Ocado announced (without naming the partner) in June.

BE11:14am

I guess we'll find out next year.

BE11:14am

The other thing helping out Ocado is a Credit Suisse push.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Over the past 4 weeks shares of Ocado have fallen greater than 20%, materially underperforming its food retailing peers. News over this period has been light, with the main potential negatives being Kantar market share data that show weaker online grocery adoption and slower Ocado growth, Morrisons' ongoing roll-out of in-store picking (for regions outside of Ocado's catchment area), and reports that Amazon is discontinuing AmazonFresh in certain US zip codes. In this report we discuss why we believe these factors do not explain the recent share price decline.

BE11:15am

Recent marketing trip underscores broad interest. We were with Ocado on a roadshow in Europe where it had a full schedule and met with a wide range of clients. We believe investors are acutely aware of the trends within food retailing and understand the importance of the online food channel. However, all of the client feedback stated an unwillingness to establish any positions in the stock until a mainstream grocer signs a deal for Ocado's Smart Platform (including the automated fulfilment centre technology). News of a deal would likely push the stock up materially given the strong signal it would send and the large and rising short interest (greater than 22%), but roadshow feedback stated that it would be worth paying that premium for reduced risk.

BE11:16am

While the potential for a 3rd-party deal remains the key catalyst, we highlight Ocado's 4Q17 trading statement on December 14 as the next official release (Ocado has a November 30 year-end). We will look for qualitative commentary around the ramp-up of Ocado's newest CFC (in Andover) to determine the engineering hurdles it is still trying to address.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

You'll remember that Credit Suisse has the most futurologist view on Ocado. As in, half its deliveries will be driverless by 2026.

BE11:17am

Gonna need a wee bit of work to get to that point, of course: https://www.thegua...in-first-uk-trials

BE11:18am

And the glorious robotised future will make Ocado cheaper than going to Sainsbury yourself. That's the theory.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

https://www.ft.com...-8526-7b38dcaef614

undefined
BE11:20am

ROTR, we have no stock market hook for the Harry/Meghan union, sorry.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Waterford Wedgwood used to be listed, and might've had a bit of a run on the prospect of more commemorative plates, but I think it's now PE owned.

BE11:21am

.... Yep. KPS Capital Partners. American LBO barbarians making our Royal souvenir tat.

BE11:22am

....... Otherwise ............................

11:22 am
BE11:22am

There's Easyjet leading us higher at the mo.

easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,392, up 27 (+1.98%), High: 1,406, Low: 1,364, Volume: 799.47k
BE11:23am

I think that's on the back of a Redburn push.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Redburn's very keen on Berlin, saying the AirBerlin purchase is "hugely profitable in the long-term"

BE11:24am

Because of a shortage of slots.

BE11:24am

Gatwick's the parallel they draw.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

(... Was the RAW autotext triggered by "draw"? Bloody hell, this system gets more temperamental every day.)

BE11:25am

Plus the old "next year, capacity growth will be more rational"

BE11:26am

None of which is in consensus right now. Redburn's 32% ahead of consensus for outer years.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Leading to a 1,900 share price target.

BE11:27am

I'm paraphrasing here because I only have a desk note on it.

BE11:28am

The upshot of which is that AirBerlin becomes accretive in 2019 and so EasyJet is currently 12x PE for high teens eps growth.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Otherwise, as noted right, we have Exane on the airline sector.

BE11:30am

Easyjet target goes up to £13

BE11:30am

Which means an upgrade to neutral. Beyond that it's mostly just forecast rejigging.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

The jet fuel forward curve and EBNPP oil team highlight a likely pullback in oil/fuel in 2018 against current spot. However, we have assumed that spot of USD600/MT prevails through 2018, and then rises by USD50/MT p.a. through our forecast period. This should be supported by a corresponding rise in underlying unit revenue across most airlines, albeit aggressive pricing on high-capacity routes will likely continue despite beneficial industry consolidation, notably the demise of Monarch.

BE11:31am

Roll over valuations to 2018, blah blah blah.

BE11:31am

With more than 20% upside to our TP’s on IAG and Lufthansa they stand as our key longs in the sector. The easyJet TP increase, collapse of Monarch and recognition of solid unit revenue momentum through winter 2017/18 on easyJet sees us increase our recommendation from Underperform to Neutral.

11:31 am
International Consolidated Airlines Group SA (IAG:LSE): Last: 603.50, up 7.5 (+1.26%), High: 607.00, Low: 595.50, Volume: 4.27m
undefined
BE11:34am

Do we stick to sellside? There ain't much else.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

I mean, the weekend press had an LSE bid story of sorts.

BE11:35am

https://www.thetim...-9957-1b360ac484a2

BE11:35am

Fears are mounting that the London Stock Exchange could fall victim to an opportunistic takeover bid as a result of its acrimonious boardroom split.

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Are they? Fears? Mounting? Are they really mounting? Those fears?

London Stock Exchange Group PLC (LSE:LSE): Last: 3,790, up 14 (+0.37%), High: 3,809, Low: 3,753, Volume: 116.97k
BE11:37am

..... Anyway, Glaxo up.

11:37 am
GlaxoSmithKline PLC (GSK:LSE): Last: 1,321, up 23 (+1.77%), High: 1,324, Low: 1,301, Volume: 2.58m
BE11:38am

UBS turn buyers. Argument is mostly, "oversold".

BE11:05am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's thing with the etc.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

It's the old "most of the earnings might disappear because a competitor has a better drug but it's already in the price" story.

BE11:40am

As in, all drug companies.

BE11:40am

We estimate GSK's HIV business ViiV accounts for c1/3 of group EBIT. The division has been the main growth engine but that will change as competitor Gilead re-enters the HIV integrase inhibitor market in 2018 taking new patient share from GSK's Tivicay/Triumeq franchise. Given GSK's EBIT dependency on ViiV, this uncertainty requires a discount to the sector in 2019 on realistic earnings base. At 13x we believe that is now priced in - a good starting point when looking at GSK as a bond proxy.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

As for the divi ..............

BE11:40am

GSK has set itself a long term 1.25-1.5x target FCF dividend cover which it will not reach in the next few years on UBSe. Substantial negative consensus earnings revisions have reinvigorated the debate as to whether GSK will cut its dividend. We disagree. We think GSK can increase cash flow generation, likely via higher CAPEX discipline and therefore consider the dividend secure.

BE11:41am

(@GBKrona: you mean buy or be bought?)

11:42 am
BE11:42am

So, in terms of Glaxo maybe buying Pfizer's OTC stuff .........

BE11:42am

As per: https://www.ft.com...-9bfb-4a9c83ffa852

BE11:42am

Too rich, says UBS.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

Including the contingent liability of £8bn that GSK has on its balance sheet for the potential Novartis put in the Consumer JV, the company's net debt/EBITDA hovers around 2.5x leaving limited debt capacity if we assume that 3x is a barrier. Of course the market then jumped back to the assumption that the dividend is even more at risk but the numbers just don't tally, in our view. With c£9bn in EBITDA we believe GSK doesn't have the balance sheet to pull off a teens billion transaction and even cutting the dividend by 1⁄4 would do little (~£1bn in additional financing capacity), in our view.

BE11:43am

Hypothetically, on our numbers, should GSK pursue an all debt/cash acquisition of Pfizer's CHC franchise this would lever the company to ~3.4-3.6x net/debt to EBITDA (proforma) and be mid-single digit percentage accretive in '18/'19.

BE11:43am

.... and Glaxo ain't going to do a rights issue down here, surely.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

The bottom line for us is that the only way we can see GSK would
be able to get its hands on the Pfizer business would be by finding a way to include the business in its existing JV. Talking about the dividend in this context is not rational in our view.

BE11:44am

Which all seems fair enough.

undefined
11:45 am
BE11:46am

Oh, hey, Citi on this Ocado Swedish thing has just dropped in.

BE11:47am

Unlikely to be a “big deal” but further proof of concept

BE11:47am

Oh.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

[ICA] will pursue a combination of dark stores and local store pick, suggesting to us that any potential agreement would have a similar structure to the deal agreed with an unnamed European regional retailer in Jun-17.

BE11:48am

But isn't ICA also an "unnamed European regional retailer"? I mean, it's Sweden's biggest grocer with a one-third market share, but is Sweden a region?

BE11:49am

Citi are buyers of Ocado, just in case you want to read some more about robots delivering stuff to your door.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

[W]e expect the development of better and cheaper technologies to increase automation throughout the grocery value chain with ‘cost-plus’, store-based fulfilment progressively giving way to grocery and broadlines fulfilment via automated warehouses. In this context, we view Ocado as the leading solutions provider in the $5.6tn global grocery market. To our minds, agreements with retailers such as ICA will underscore – and begin to crystallize – this potential.

BE11:51am

And here's the counterpoint on robots delivering things to your door.

BE11:51am

https://twitter.com/physiologic_al/status/931625336088997888

11:51 am
undefined
BE11:55am

Couple of floats worth mentioning.

BE11:55am

Beeks Financial Cloud, for example.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Heading onto Aim after raising £7m

BE11:56am

Cenkos did the business.

BE11:56am

Gordon McArthur, CEO of Beeks Financial Cloud, commented, “We are delighted to be joining AIM today in what marks a significant milestone for the Company. As a growing technology provider for automated trading, we believe that public company status and the new funds raised will enable us to accelerate our clear organic and acquisitive growth strategy.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

I'm just going to hoof up the background par here, because it's a mug's game trying to paraphrase this stuff.

BE11:58am

Background to the Company Connecting and managing low latency environments is complex and time consuming to establish, as well as expensive to maintain. Mid-tier institutions are unlikely to be able to build the infrastructure and make the connections required themselves and many choose Beeks to manage their automated trading routes for them. By choosing Beeks as a service provider, financial institutions can reduce IT overheads in their business and trade in a variety of markets and test and deploy new strategies without significant cost or down-time. Beeks can cater for the requirements of these traders from a cloud based platform, allowing them to trade on a ''pay for what you use'' model.

BE11:59am

It then goes on to explain what algo trading is. Anyway, shares 48p live.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

There was also Keystone Law .....

BE11:59am

.... the first ‘challenger’ law firm to list on the public market .....

BE11:59am

Trading 189.5p vs a placing price of 160p.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

And it's ... uh, it's a law firm.

BE12:00pm

A strongly cash generative financial model with negligible fixed direct costs and with scope for further operating margin enhancement: Keystone’s lawyers are self-employed, working from their own offices with no fixed or minimum remuneration. A substantial part of Keystone’s overhead base is fixed and the Directors are of the view that there is significant scope for operating margins to increase as the business grows. The Group also has a strong cash generation profile, since lawyers are only paid once Keystone has been paid.

BE12:01pm

£7.4m of the £9m raised is going to pay off note holders.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Panmure did the duty here.

BE12:02pm

Keystone has over 250 high calibre, experienced, self-employed lawyers, who contract with the Group predominantly through personal service companies.

BE12:02pm

Hm.

12:02 pm
undefined
BE12:03pm

SO it's through midday and I've got a headahe but I promised something or other on miners, so here's something or other on miners.

BE12:04pm

Specifically, Macquarie's regular pricing thing.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

BE12:06pm

(@BornCynic: Indeed. It rhymes with Sassenach.)

BE12:06pm

That compares to .....

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

BE12:07pm

Since September, the market appears to have grown less incredulous about the sustainability of spot commodity prices. The average discount to spot being priced into the diversified miners has dropped from 14% at the beginning of September to 9% today. This partly reflects the correction in the prices of iron ore and coking coal since then, which have fallen by 20% and 10%, respectively; to levels the market considers more reasonable. In contrast, base metal prices have barely budged over the period while alumina has rallied by 30%

BE12:07pm

The analysis reinforces our Outperform recommendations on Glencore and KAZ which enjoy a clear valuation advantage over their respective peer groups. Moreover, Glencore’s heavy base metal bend and defensive trading division should place the company in a strong position to outperform the other majors in 2018, while KAZ’ copper grade upside offers earnings upgrade potential.

12:07 pm
Kaz Minerals PLC (KAZ:LSE): Last: 820.00, down 17 (-2.03%), High: 829.50, Low: 818.50, Volume: 392.33k
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 361.10, down 1.25 (-0.34%), High: 362.30, Low: 358.10, Volume: 5.33m
BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 1,411, no change, High: 1,415, Low: 1,396, Volume: 1.89m
12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

Etc.

undefined
BE12:08pm

Okay, we're done, let's close, enough.

12:09 pm
BE12:09pm

Go read this very good if not entirely sincere Lex note on why Japan Tobacco should buy Mondelez. https://www.ft.com...-9dbb-291a884dd8c6

BE12:09pm

We'll be back tomorrow.

BE12:10pm

Oh, hey, actually! I forgot about Pearson!

12:10 pm
Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 695.00, down 13 (-1.84%), High: 706.50, Low: 693.00, Volume: 1.27m
BE12:10pm

They've sold Wall Street English for nearly nothing.

BE12:11pm

Gross cash of $300m, which doesn't look that bad against press reports ahead of time of $350m-$400m.

12:11 pm
BE12:11pm

What wasn't mentioned in the (one assumed quite well sourced) press reports was that tax and miscellaneous transaction fees would cost $50m!

BE12:12pm

And there's another $150m of operating cash trapped in the business, because students pay upfront.

BE12:13pm

So, you're looking at $100m net, which is rather less than the $400m flagged.

12:13 pm
BE12:13pm

I mean, it's a tiny deal. £7m operating earnings.

BE12:14pm

And the argument is that it simplifies the job Fallon has to do. Still, maybe those giving the steers on value beforehand could've thought more about the reveal when the news was announced.

undefined
12:14 pm
BE12:14pm

Right, we really are done now.

BE12:15pm

Go away. See you tomorrow. Afternoon all.

BE11:39am

We upgrade GSK to Buy as we believe concerns of continuing earnings decline and the dividend sustainability are now over-done. Things will likely get tougher for GSK's earnings before they get better with 2018 showing a decline and no growth 2019 on our estimates. Over this time horizon OPEX increases, Advair generic erosion and increasing competition in HIV (ViiV) coincide. But GSK should then emerge from its earnings plateau. Uncertainty around the ViiV trajectory does justify a discount to the sector but we believe the valuation now reflects that (10% discount on '19 PE). Against market belief the dividend looks secure in our view and investors should be rewarded with two years of 80p before there is an opportunity to decide whether there is ‘gold at the end of the rainbow’ (2019E 3-year PEG of 2.2x v sector average of 2.6x). Our estimates change slightly due to phasing of respiratory revenues and a reduction in other operating income. We upgrade to Buy, PT 1,550p
